title: Mini Project 4
text:
On this page, we will take a very brief look at the tweets from POTUS and FLOTUS on Twitter (now known as X) during the Obama Administration.











To start simple, we can observe from the graph above that tweets from either Barack or Michelle tended to be no longer than 150 characters long, with the exception of a couple towards the end of 2016 - possibly signifying tweets relating to the end of the Obama Administration?









With this graph, we make a tiny modification by concerning ourselves with the number of words in each tweet rather than the number of characters. We can see that the patterns between the two are largely the same - which is unsuprising. Word counts also tend to not surpass 30, which could suggest an average of 5 characters per word used? Although, character count would also include punctuation and spacing, so this is likely a flawed conjecture. Regardless, it is apparent that these tweets are often pretty brief - but there are many!



Barack and Michelle are Christian, and so we could take one approach to see how much of a relevance this had on their tweets by searching for how many included a mention of God.


# A tibble: 2 × 4
  person   num_tweets_with_god     n percentage_tweets_with_god
  <chr>                  <int> <int>                      <dbl>
1 Barack                     2   321                   0.00623 
2 Michelle                   4  4018                   0.000996


As it turns out, not very many at all. Indeed, I calculated percentages here but those are barely meaningful - Barack and Michelle combined only mentioned God 6 times in their tweets. This is not necessarily suggestive of lack of faith - perhaps just a pointer to a possible commitment to separation of state and church.



Finally, being the President and First Lady, Barack and Michelle would likely focus their tweets around spreading positive messages.









Indeed, a quick text analysis reveal that the top ten words both of these folks use are of a positive sentiment (and overlap heavily)! They have a commitment to ensuring that the country they serve is healthy and supported!

title: Mini Project 1
text:
library(ggthemes)
library(htmltools)
library(leaflet)
library(maps)
library(sf)
library(tidyr)
library(tidyverse)
library(viridis)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)

# Load mapping data
us_states <- tibble(map_data("state"))
sf_states <- read_sf("https://rstudio.github.io/leaflet/json/us-states.geojson")

#   industrial_processes <dbl>, agriculture <dbl>, waste <dbl>, lucf <dbl>,
#   bunker_fuels <dbl>, electric_power <dbl>, commercial <dbl>,
#   residential <dbl>, industrial <dbl>, transportation <dbl>,
#   fugitive_emissions <dbl>, state_gdp <dbl>, population <dbl>,
#   total_energy_use <dbl>











Alt text (since I’m not sure if PDFs can be inspected to see the alt text in the element):
This is a map of the states of the United States of America. Each is colored to depict the state’s emission levels from the energy sector, ranging from 0 to 800 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. The colorings of the states suggest that most midwestern states have levels under 200, eastern states tend to be around 300 except for the far northeastern area. California stands out with its color, showing a level around 400, and Texas stands out the most with a level of around 800.









Alt text
This is a map of the states of the United States of America. Each has one of four colors to depict the state’s total greenhouse gas emissions, not accounting for the land use sector. Yellow means under 100 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent, green means between 100 and 300, blue means between 300 and 500, and purple is over 500. Most midwestern states along with the northeastern states and a couple southeastern states are yellow. Most central states and a few southwestern states are green. California is the only blue state, and Texas is the only purple state.
Link to Github for code, including that for the interactive plots
https://github.com/Sloth186/SDS264_S25/tree/main/Mini%20Project%201

title: Shen Rothermel
text: Greetings and salutations! My name is Shen Rothermel and I am currently a Junior at St. Olaf College in Northfield, working towards my Computer Science & Mathematics degree. My hobbies are numerous, but amongst them are anime, gaming, coding, and hanging out with my friends! I also immensely enjoy cats. Cats are very important.

title: Mini-Project 2
text:
In this project, we explored soccer statistics from multiple professional football leagues using data from FBref (https://fbref.com/en/comps/22/Major-League-Soccer-Stats), a trusted site for advanced football analytics. While we initially focused on Major League Soccer (MLS), we extended our analysis to include other major international competitions such as the Premier League, La Liga, Bundesliga, and Serie A.
Our goal was to collect and organize standardized squad-level statistics across leagues to support comparative analysis. Specifically, we targeted the “Squad Standard Stats” tables on each competition’s main stats page. These tables contain information on team performance metrics such as matches played, goals, assists, average age, possession %, and more.

title: Mini-Project 2
text:
In this project, we explored soccer statistics from multiple professional football leagues using data from FBref (https://fbref.com/en/comps/22/Major-League-Soccer-Stats), a trusted site for advanced football analytics. While we initially focused on Major League Soccer (MLS), we extended our analysis to include other major international competitions such as the Premier League, La Liga, Bundesliga, and Serie A.
Our goal was to collect and organize standardized squad-level statistics across leagues to support comparative analysis. Specifically, we targeted the “Squad Standard Stats” tables on each competition’s main stats page. These tables contain information on team performance metrics such as matches played, goals, assists, average age, possession %, and more.

title: Mini-Project 2
text:
Motivation
We chose this dataset primarily out of personal interest: one of us enjoys following global football news, while the other is an avid FC25 player. Beyond our curiosity, we recognized that this data offers a rich opportunity for cross-league comparisons.
By scraping the same type of statistics from each league, we aimed to answer questions such as:

Do older squads tend to score more or less?
Is there a relationship between average age and possession percentage?
How does team performance (e.g., goals, assists) vary across leagues?

These questions open the door for future data visualizations (like scatterplots or heatmaps) and statistical modeling (e.g., regression of goals on age or possession).
To acquire the data, we used a custom scraping function along with an iteration technique (pmap) to systematically collect comparable squad stats from each league’s respective webpage. This ensures consistency while handling slight variations in webpage structure — such as differing table positions.

title: Mini-Project 2
text:
Scraping the “Squad Standard Stats” table:
To begin, we manually scrape the Major League Soccer (MLS) stats page using rvest. This allows us to locate and inspect the structure of all tables on the page, which helps identify the correct table containing squad-level statistics.
Once we confirm the correct table is loaded (in this case, table 5), we clean it by promoting the first row to column headers, standardizing names, and parsing numeric columns. This results in a tidy dataset ready for analysis.

title: Mini-Project 2
section: Creating a Custom Web Scraping Function:
text:
Creating a Custom Web Scraping Function:
Next, we generalize this scraping process by writing a custom function called scrape_fbref_table(). This function takes in a URL and table number and performs all the cleaning steps automatically. We use it to easily scrape multiple pages later on.

Squad2_cleaned

# A tibble: 30 × 16
   squad  number_pl   age  poss    mp starts   min  x90s   gls   ast   g_a  g_pk
